Yes, I believe filmmakers today could certainly learn from Frank Lloyd's approach to portraying social issues in film. Lloyd's films were notable for their nuanced and thoughtful exploration of complex issues like race, class, and nationalism. He was able to create sympathetic portrayals of marginalized individuals while also highlighting the ways in which social systems and power structures can lead to inequality and oppression.

I think Lloyd's approach has enduring relevance for filmmakers today. As our society continues to grapple with issues related to social justice and equality, filmmakers have an important role to play in helping audiences understand and empathize with the experiences of marginalized individuals. By taking a page from Lloyd's book and creating films that explore these issues in a thoughtful and nuanced way, filmmakers today can help spark important conversations and promote greater understanding and social change.
